description:
Bodo saltans is a species of free-living, heterotrophic flagellate protist belonging to the phylum Euglenozoa. It is a single-celled eukaryotic organism that moves by means of two flagella, which it uses to propel itself in a characteristic jumping or "saltatory" motion, hence the specific epithet "saltans" meaning "jumping" in Latin.

Bodo saltans is commonly found in freshwater environments, such as ponds, lakes, and streams, where it feeds on bacteria and other microorganisms. It is typically oval or pear-shaped, with a length ranging from 10 to 20 micrometers. The two flagella are unequal in length, with one being longer and used for locomotion, while the shorter one is used for sensing the environment.

Bodo saltans reproduces asexually through binary fission, where the cell divides into two daughter cells, each inheriting a copy of the genetic material. It is considered an important component of aquatic microbial food webs, serving as a link between bacteria and higher trophic levels in the ecosystem.
